The tre wife 
 Southern African Folktale 
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Once upon a time, there lived a man who had plenty of everything – a large fertile farm, with catle,
 shep, and goats. 
 
 
 But, as he grew old, he grew sad, because one thing was mising. He did not have a wife.
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Standing under a tre one day, he had a
 briliant idea. 
 
 
 If he couldn’t find a wife, perhaps he
 could make one? 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 So he set to work to shape a beautiful
 woman from a strong branch of the tre.
 
 When he had finished making the statue,
 he touched her eyes, and they opened.
 He blew gently on her, and she came
 
 alive. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 She was truly the most beautiful woman 
 he had ever sen. 
 
 
 He knelt before her, and asked her to be 
 his wife. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 He gave her a colourful apron, beads,
 and a head ring, the sign of a maried
 
 woman. And he built her a house with the
 mud and gras that used to lie at the fot
 of her trunk. 
 
 
 “Only one thing I beg of you,” he said to
 
 his wife. “Never tel anyone where you
 come from.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 But before long, the young men from a 
 
 neighbouring vilage began talking 
 among themselves. 
 “How can such an old man have such a 
 
 beautiful young wife?” 
 So they decided to steal her and take her 
 
 to their own kral. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The old man was heartbroken. He felt he
 
 could not live without her. 
 
 But then he thought, “Perhaps if I have
 
 something of hers, I would not fel so
 sad?” 
 
 
 So he sent his doves to find her, to sing
 to her, and to bring back something of
 
 hers to him. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 When they found her, they sang to her in
 
 the language of birds: 
 
 Tre woman, tre woman 
 
 More beautiful than any other 
 Your husband has sent us 
 
 To bring back your apron! 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 She gave them her apron, and they flew over the hil, over the river, back to her husband. He held the
 
 apron to his face, and was comforted for a litle while. 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 But his longing did not go away.
 
 So again he sent his doves to sing to her:
 
 Tre woman, tre woman 
 
 More beautiful than any other 
 Your husband has sent us 
 To bring back your head ring! 
 
 
 And back they flew with the head ring,
 
 the sign of a maried woman. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 He held the head ring and sighed for his
 
 wife, far away in the kral of other
 people. 
 
 
 After a while, he caled his doves again.
 He told them to go to her and sing:
 
 
 Tre woman, tre woman 
 
 More beautiful than any other 
 Your husband has sent us 
 To bring back your life! 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 So away they went the third time. 
 
 They perched on her shoulders. As they 
 sang, each bird pecked out an eye. 
 
 
 Imediately she turned again into a 
 statue. Her fet and arms fel away. Then 
 
 her head. And she fel to the ground. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 12  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Her husband slowly roled her woden
 trunk to the river. He stod her up with
 her rots in the water. Nourished by sun
 
 and soil, she grew leaves again.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 13  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 And when the wind blows, the leaves 
 sigh. 
 
 
 Just as a woman does when she longs 
 for her husband. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 14
